title: 111_hr4620
content: The "Small Business Job Creation Act of 2010" includes a temporary work opportunity credit for small businesses. The "Small Business Job Creation Act of 2010" introduces a small business credit for hiring certain unemployed individuals during 2010 and 2011. Eligible small businesses can elect to treat these individuals as a targeted group for tax purposes. The Small Business Job Creation Act of 2010 offers a tax credit for hiring eligible unemployed individuals. To qualify, a small business must have had a total revenue of less than $20,000,000 in the previous year or employed fewer than 200 full-time employees. An eligible unemployed individual is defined as someone certified by the designated local authority. To qualify for the tax credit under the Small Business Job Creation Act of 2010, an individual must be certified as eligible for unemployment compensation and work full-time, averaging at least 30 hours per week. The modifications for the tax credit under the Small Business Job Creation Act of 2010 include changing the percentage of wages for 2010 and 2011, adjusting qualified wages taken into account, and implementing a $75,000 wage limitation. The Small Business Job Creation Act of 2010 includes a $75,000 wage limitation and a double credit for employers in high unemployment counties. The Small Business Job Creation Act of 2010 includes provisions for high unemployment counties, with exceptions for certain rehires and an effective date of January 1, 2010.
